description:
This PR includes fixes to help with porting eps_writer to 3.0 and an addition to multiplot to allow 
user defined labels.
title: Updates to port eps_writer to 3.0

content.raw:
@john_regan thanks for the contribution! It's great to have this in before 3.1.

Can you merge with the tip of the yt branch on yt_analysis/yt to clear the conflict?
content.html:
John Regan thanks for the contribution! It's great to have this in before 3.1.

Can you merge with the tip of the yt branch on yt_analysis/yt to clear the conflict?

content.raw:
@ngoldbaum what's the easiest way to do that? I tried syncing using bitbucket but that wasn't a runner - just identified the conflict. 
Maybe hg pull yt_analysis/yt into my fork and then commit and push again?
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum what's the easiest way to do that? I tried syncing using bitbucket but that wasn't a runner - just identified the conflict. Maybe hg pull yt_analysis/yt into my fork and then commit and push again?

content.raw:
```
#!bash

hg up 6357bbc
hg pull https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt
hg merge yt
<fix conflicts>
hg commit
hg push https://bitbucket.org/john_regan/yt-3.0-dev-eps
```

Also, FWIW, it's not necessary to create a new fork just for a single one-off pull request.  You can have multiple heads on your bitbucket fork and can issue multiple simultaneous pull requests from your fork.
content.html:
hg up 6357bbc
hg pull https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt
hg merge yt
<fix conflicts>
hg commit
hg push https://bitbucket.org/john_regan/yt-3.0-dev-eps

Also, FWIW, it's not necessary to create a new fork just for a single one-off pull request. You can have multiple heads on your bitbucket fork and can issue multiple simultaneous pull requests from your fork.

content.raw: @ngoldbaum Yeah I need to start having multiple heads on my forks I know - new year resolution perhaps! Thanks for hg tutorial :)
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum Yeah I need to start having multiple heads on my forks I know - new year resolution perhaps! Thanks for hg tutorial :)

content.raw: @jwise77 mind giving this a test run?
content.html: John Wise mind giving this a test run?

content.raw: @ngoldbaum that worked very nicely - thanks. Conflicts should be resolved now....
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum that worked very nicely - thanks. Conflicts should be resolved now....

content.raw: Sure thing. I was waiting for the conflicts to be fixed!
content.html: Sure thing. I was waiting for the conflicts to be fixed!

content.raw:
I think some of the latest changes broke the leading imports in the eps_writer.
```
#!python

  File "/home/jwise/codes/yt-clean/yt/visualization/eps_writer.py", line 24, in <module>
    from .plot_modifications import get_smallest_appropriate_unit
ImportError: cannot import name get_smallest_appropriate_unit
```
content.html:
I think some of the latest changes broke the leading imports in the eps_writer.

  File "/home/jwise/codes/yt-clean/yt/visualization/eps_writer.py", line 24, in <module>
    from .plot_modifications import get_smallest_appropriate_unit
ImportError: cannot import name get_smallest_appropriate_unit

content.raw: Ah yes, that was changed in [PR 1347](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-request/1347/bugfix-dont-set-code_length-as-the-length/diff).  The fix is to use `ds.get_smallest_appropriate_unit()` instead.
content.html: Ah yes, that was changed in PR 1347. The fix is to use ds.get_smallest_appropriate_unit() instead.

content.raw: Revert the change to units
content.html: Revert the change to units

content.raw:
In line 312, there is a typo (from a previous changeset),

```
#!python
yax = plot.ds.coordinatesyx_axis[data.axis]
```

I think that should be `plot.ds.coordinates.y_axis[data.axis]`.
content.html:
In line 312, there is a typo (from a previous changeset),

yax = plot.ds.coordinatesyx_axis[data.axis]

I think that should be plot.ds.coordinates.y_axis[data.axis].

content.raw:
I cannot get the eps_writer to make a simple single plot with these changes and the merge without making various changes. @john_regan Can you create any type of figures after the merge?  Here is the code that I was using,

```
#!python

import yt
import yt.visualization.eps_writer as eps

pf = yt.load("galaxy0030/galaxy0030")
slc = yt.SlicePlot(pf, 'z', ['density'])#, 'temperature', 'pressure', 'velocity_magnitude'])
slc.set_width(25, 'kpc')
eps_fig = eps.single_plot(slc, field=('gas', 'density'))
eps_fig.save_fig('zoom', format='eps')
```
content.html:
I cannot get the eps_writer to make a simple single plot with these changes and the merge without making various changes. John Regan Can you create any type of figures after the merge? Here is the code that I was using,

import yt
import yt.visualization.eps_writer as eps

pf = yt.load("galaxy0030/galaxy0030")
slc = yt.SlicePlot(pf, 'z', ['density'])#, 'temperature', 'pressure', 'velocity_magnitude'])
slc.set_width(25, 'kpc')
eps_fig = eps.single_plot(slc, field=('gas', 'density'))
eps_fig.save_fig('zoom', format='eps')

content.raw: Ok so the merge broke the eps_writer again? I'm out of time here tonight but I'll have a look again in the morning.
content.html: Ok so the merge broke the eps_writer again? I'm out of time here tonight but I'll have a look again in the morning.

content.raw: There are still some issues in the eps_writer when it tries to save a plot - it fails due to a units issue. I haven't seen this before so I'll need to take a look at it....
content.html: There are still some issues in the eps_writer when it tries to save a plot - it fails due to a units issue. I haven't seen this before so I'll need to take a look at it....

content.raw: ah I didn't see it before because I always set "bare_axes=True". I'm dipping in and out of this debug between other things....
content.html: ah I didn't see it before because I always set "bare_axes=True". I'm dipping in and out of this debug between other things....

content.raw: That would make sense since it's failing on determining the units for the axes.  Thanks for updating this for us.
content.html: That would make sense since it's failing on determining the units for the axes. Thanks for updating this for us.

content.raw:
This works for the most part now. There appear to be some issues further up the stack with regard labelling. For example the phase plot for a density-temperature plot fails to tex the density label properly. Where is that label created? - its outside the scope of the eps_writer anyway. Also, when creating a projection plot the eps_writer calls - get_label(proj) - that is not supported it seems. I inserted a 
try-catch to stop the failure and with the cb_labels mechanism the user can insert his/her own. Again this issue is outside the scope of the eps_writer though.
content.html: This works for the most part now. There appear to be some issues further up the stack with regard labelling. For example the phase plot for a density-temperature plot fails to tex the density label properly. Where is that label created? - its outside the scope of the eps_writer anyway. Also, when creating a projection plot the eps_writer calls - get_label(proj) - that is not supported it seems. I inserted a try-catch to stop the failure and with the cb_labels mechanism the user can insert his/her own. Again this issue is outside the scope of the eps_writer though.

content.raw: What about `PhasePlot._get_field_label` (line 760 of profile_plotter.py)?
content.html: What about PhasePlot._get_field_label (line 760 of profile_plotter.py)?

content.raw: For projection plots, you can see how we generate the labels there inside in the `PWViewerMPL._setup_plots` function. The x and y labels start on line 768 of plot_window.py and the colorbar label comes from the FRB, near line 855.
content.html: For projection plots, you can see how we generate the labels there inside in the PWViewerMPL._setup_plots function. The x and y labels start on line 768 of plot_window.py and the colorbar label comes from the FRB, near line 855.

content.raw: I'll take a look - thanks.
content.html: I'll take a look - thanks.

content.raw: @ngoldbaum I'm having trouble finding getting the correct formal arguments for the call to _get_field_label. I need to get access to the field (density so the xfield), field info and field unit but I'm not sure where they live - do you know? - or perhaps @jwise77 does?
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum I'm having trouble finding getting the correct formal arguments for the call to _get_field_label. I need to get access to the field (density so the xfield), field info and field unit but I'm not sure where they live - do you know? - or perhaps John Wise does?

content.raw:
Can you paste an example script that's failing on the current tip of your PR?

A big problem with this code is that it's completely untested. We should invest the effort to write minimal tests.
content.html:
Can you paste an example script that's failing on the current tip of your PR?

A big problem with this code is that it's completely untested. We should invest the effort to write minimal tests.

content.raw:
```
#!python

import yt
import yt.visualization.eps_writer as eps

pf = yt.load("RD0009/RD0009")
ad = pf.all_data()
phase = yt.PhasePlot(ad, 'density', 'temperature', ["cell_mass"],
                     weight_field=None)
eps_fig = eps.single_plot(phase)
eps_fig.save_fig('phase', format='png')
```
content.html:
import yt
import yt.visualization.eps_writer as eps

pf = yt.load("RD0009/RD0009")
ad = pf.all_data()
phase = yt.PhasePlot(ad, 'density', 'temperature', ["cell_mass"],
                     weight_field=None)
eps_fig = eps.single_plot(phase)
eps_fig.save_fig('phase', format='png')

content.raw: That should fail on trying to "tex" the density label up. I've to shoot off now for a couple of hours. If you leave any comments I'll get to it later.
content.html: That should fail on trying to "tex" the density label up. I've to shoot off now for a couple of hours. If you leave any comments I'll get to it later.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw:
The issue seems to be that pyx doesn't like the `\frac` latex sequence in the unit label. Unfortunately to make it so we can get field units without the \frac sequence requires monkeying with the unit system...

I'll look at this this weekend, see if I can get this cleared up.
content.html:
The issue seems to be that pyx doesn't like the \frac latex sequence in the unit label. Unfortunately to make it so we can get field units without the \frac sequence requires monkeying with the unit system...

I'll look at this this weekend, see if I can get this cleared up.

content.raw: I found a workaround for the `\frac` issue.  I have some changesets from several months ago that I never finalized (before getting distracted with other things) that I can provide.  Let me package them together, so they can be included in this PR.
content.html: I found a workaround for the \frac issue. I have some changesets from several months ago that I never finalized (before getting distracted with other things) that I can provide. Let me package them together, so they can be included in this PR.

content.raw: I created issue #965 to address this.
content.html: I created issue #965 to address this.

content.raw: @john_regan I applied all of my (uncommitted) changes plus some conflicts and updates in my [yt-clean](https://bitbucket.org/jwise77/yt-clean/commits/all) fork on top of your changes. Can you pull these changesets into your fork and test them out? They worked on the testing scripts that I have written in the past. If you're curious, the `\frac` is converted from LaTeX to TeX in `pyxize_label()`.
content.html: John Regan I applied all of my (uncommitted) changes plus some conflicts and updates in my yt-clean fork on top of your changes. Can you pull these changesets into your fork and test them out? They worked on the testing scripts that I have written in the past. If you're curious, the \frac is converted from LaTeX to TeX in pyxize_label().

content.raw: @jwise77 That sounds great. I'll pull those changes into my fork and test it as soon as I get a chance (likely to be a few days away though). I'm very curious to see how you worked around the \frac issue - great work!
content.html: John Wise That sounds great. I'll pull those changes into my fork and test it as soon as I get a chance (likely to be a few days away though). I'm very curious to see how you worked around the \frac issue - great work!

content.raw: No rush.  Happy holidays!
content.html: No rush. Happy holidays!

content.raw: @jwise77 The single plot tests passed but I see a failure in one of my multiplot tests. I've pasted the script I used here [Script](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5318/) and I used dataset RD0009 from enzo_tiny_cosmology. It's failing in get_log but I can't see why.... I think this code was updated in the latest revision though.
content.html: John Wise The single plot tests passed but I see a failure in one of my multiplot tests. I've pasted the script I used here Script and I used dataset RD0009 from enzo_tiny_cosmology. It's failing in get_log but I can't see why.... I think this code was updated in the latest revision though.

content.raw: Hi all, this looks pretty ready to go -- are we waiting on the answer updates?
content.html: Hi all, this looks pretty ready to go -- are we waiting on the answer updates?

content.raw: There is a failure in the multiplot api in John W's revision which we should clear up and commit the two PR's together. It looks like some mix up in the order of the objects sent to the eps writer (it works for corner cases but not in general). It should be cleared up in the next day or so I imagine. This PR depends on the tex workaround John W has implemented.
content.html: There is a failure in the multiplot api in John W's revision which we should clear up and commit the two PR's together. It looks like some mix up in the order of the objects sent to the eps writer (it works for corner cases but not in general). It should be cleared up in the next day or so I imagine. This PR depends on the tex workaround John W has implemented.

content.raw: Can we include this as is, and then issue updates as need be?
content.html: Can we include this as is, and then issue updates as need be?

content.raw: Could you include in the docstring something about what cb_labels expects?  I'm guessing a string that acts as the colorbar label, but it might be good to clarify for users so they can just look at the API reference without having to open up the source.
content.html: Could you include in the docstring something about what cb_labels expects? I'm guessing a string that acts as the colorbar label, but it might be good to clarify for users so they can just look at the API reference without having to open up the source.

content.raw: Yes I think so. @jwise77 might want to chime in though as it would be optimal if his PR was incorporated as well.
content.html: Yes I think so. John Wise might want to chime in though as it would be optimal if his PR was incorporated as well.

content.raw: Done. I hadn't included a comment before as this function shouldn't really be called directly by the user. In fact it might be a good idea to rename this function to _colorbar_yt to emphasise that point - the next update perhaps :)
content.html: Done. I hadn't included a comment before as this function shouldn't really be called directly by the user. In fact it might be a good idea to rename this function to _colorbar_yt to emphasise that point - the next update perhaps :)

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.html: Hi John Regan, can you include my commits in your PR? I never issued a PR with those commits. I think if you transplant them into your fork and (automatically) update the PR, it should be good to go, barring any conflicts or errors.

There is a failure in the get_log - well that's where it bails anyway. In the multiplot call there seems to be a problem with the objects in the plots. Have you tries to run the script above?

content.html: John Regan will you be pulling John Wise's changes in today?

content.raw: I haven't tried your changes yet, and I don't have time to test things out today.  Does everything work fine without my commits?  I think we can go ahead with your PR for the 3.1 release and wait until afterwards to include my changes and address the get_log() issue.

content.html: Have you pushed your changes to your fork? I have some time today to look at this. I'd like to get your changes in before 3.1 goes out. Maybe I can fix the issue with get_log as well.

content.html: My changes work except the labelling issue for which you provided the workaround (i.e. pyxize). However, that's not a major block as the cb_labels field can be used in the meantime.

content.html: I can push John Wise changes to this fork in about an hour's time will that work? Or maybe it's easier to create a separate fork with both changes included?

content.raw: Please push them to this fork. That way the pull request will get updated.
content.html: Please push them to this fork. That way the pull request will get updated.

content.raw: The PR is now updated. All of the tests pass except the multiplot tests which gives a Key Error. The [MultiPlotTest](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5318/) script shows the error.
content.html: The PR is now updated. All of the tests pass except the multiplot tests which gives a Key Error. The MultiPlotTest script shows the error.

content.raw: This should be `yt_plots[index]`.  After fixing this issue I'm able to run your test plotting script.
content.html: This should be yt_plots[index]. After fixing this issue I'm able to run your test plotting script.

content.html: Ah well spotted! PR updated.
